centralQuestion: Should Connecticut implement a heavier redistributive tax on its wealthiest residents to reduce instate inequality?

reasons.description: Progressive taxes targeted at high-income households can help reduce Connecticut’s large local inequality and generate revenue for priority services.

sources.title: Urban Institute: 'The Upside—Growth, Potential, and the Future of Fairfield County, Connecticut'
Economic Policy Institute: 'Income inequality in the U.S. by state, metropolitan area, and county'

reasons.description: Research summaries used by policy analysts find that millionaire migration responses to higher top state tax rates are typically small, suggesting limited risk of large tax-base flight.

sources.title: Tax Policy Center: 'What Republicans and Democrats Can Learn from the Myth of Millionaire Tax Flight'
Urban Institute: 'State and Local Government Revenues and Racial Disparities'

reasons.description: Public opinion research shows strong support for raising taxes on very high incomes and wealthy households, which is often cited to justify state-level redistribution.

sources.title: Pew Research Center: 'Most Americans continue to favor raising taxes on very wealthy individuals and large corporations'
Pew Research Center: 'As they rate the economy negatively, Americans see little need for new programs — but favor raising taxes on high earners and large companies'

reasons.description: Recent state experience shows that surtaxes on high earners can raise substantial dedicated revenues for education and transportation.

sources.title: Politico: 'Here’s what’s in the long budget deal'
Politico: 'Transit, arts, and years of question marks: How Mass. will spend your new surtax'

objections.description: Higher taxes on the wealthy may prompt tax avoidance or outmigration of top earners, undermining the intended revenue gains.

sources.title: American Enterprise Institute: 'More concerns with the Massachusetts “millionaires tax”'
Reuters: 'Breakingviews: Wooing of GE is lesson for wannabe Amazon HQs'
Tax Policy Center: 'Do millionaires adjust capital gains realizations when taxes change?'

objections.description: Greater reliance on revenue from high-income households can increase budget volatility, especially when capital gains fluctuate.

sources.title: Pew Research Center: 'State Tax Revenue Volatility Varies Across States — and It’s Increasing in Some'
Politico: 'California’s deficit is one of U.S.’s worst. Biden’s tariffs could deepen it.'

objections.description: Wealth-focused taxes can be administratively complex at the subnational level, creating design and enforcement challenges.

sources.title: Tax Policy Center: 'Understanding taxes that can raise revenues to help offset growing wealth inequality in the District of Columbia'
OECD: 'The Role and Design of Net Wealth Taxes in the OECD'

objections.description: Business climate concerns are frequently cited, including examples of firms shifting activity away from Connecticut after tax hikes or proposals.

sources.title: Associated Press: 'GE’s unplugging leaves many unsettled in Connecticut town'
Reuters: 'GE move blow to Connecticut, boost for once run-down Boston area'

research.title: Journal of Economic Perspectives: 'Taxation and Migration: Evidence and Policy Implications'
research.description: A review of empirical evidence on how personal taxes affect geographic mobility, emphasizing that migration responses vary by context and population; cautions against overgeneralizing mobility elasticities when designing redistributive policy.

research.title: American Sociological Review: 'Millionaire Migration and Taxation of the Elite: Evidence from Administrative Data'
research.description: Analyzes administrative data on U.S. millionaires and finds millionaire tax flight occurs but is small; provides multi-state evidence on the limited migration response to top tax rates.

research.title: National Tax Journal: 'Millionaire Migration and State Taxation of Top Incomes: Evidence from a Natural Experiment'
research.description: Studies New Jersey’s millionaire tax and finds little evidence of substantial outmigration in response to higher top marginal rates, suggesting limited erosion of the tax base.
